POEMS IN ENGLISH - No. 10
William Butler Yeats
"FOR ANNE GREGORY"
Never shall a young man.
Thrown into despair
By those great honey-coloured
Restarts at your ear.
Love you for yourself alone
And not your yellow hair.
But I can get a hair-dye
And set such colour thAre,
Brown, or black, or carrot.
That young men in despair
May love me for myself alone
And not me yellow hair.
I heard an old religious man
But yesternight declare
That he had found a text to prove
That only God, my dear.
Could love you for yourself alone
And not your yellow hair.
I. A BRIEF PARAPHRASE
A conversation between an older man and his friend Anne Gregory, a
beautiful young girl. The elderly man tells t&e girl that no young man
could distinguish between her physical beauty (represented by her lovely
blonde hair), and her spiritual beauty. She playfully answers that she
could dye her hair, change the color of it so that young men would not be
attracted to her by its yellow color. The wise friend answers that actually,
no human being can love her for herself alone - that only God can distinguish
body and spirit as separate qualities.

hair-dye (n.s.)s a preparation for changing the color of the hair
ramparts (ii.pl. )s fortifications; barricades; defensive structures
text (n.s.)$ Here: a passage in a religious book,
yesternight (n.s.;Archaic): last night
